intro: Sida spinosa f. albiflora, commonly known as the whiteflower sida, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems and small, white to pale yellow flowers that bloom in clusters. Its leaves are ovate with serrated edges and are typically covered in fine hairs. This variety is often found in moist, disturbed soils and is adapted to thrive in wetland environments.
